pros:
I've worked at ARUP a little under 2 years now in specimen processing. To be honest the work did get repetitive to me quick however, there are a few other positions in that department you could apply for after you gain some experience. It helps that you're allowed to wear headphones so you can listen to music or podcasts which helps the day go by quick. 

I know others on here have mentioned they found specimen processing to be a toxic work environment or had a bad experience however, although certainly not perfect and occasionally there have been conflicts, I personally have had a great time working here and consider the environment and vibe to be overall positive, friendly, and supportive. Everyone I've worked with in this department especially management has been very approachable, professional, and kind. Even after working here for almost 2 years I forget some procedures and people are always willing to help if you have any questions. 

In addition to that I think they have great benefits, some of them being partial tuition reimbursement (after you reach your 6 month mark you can be reimbursed approximately $3,000-$3,500 per year for tuition however, I don't remember the exact number), a free employee health clinic, and profit sharing between all employees I believe it's every quarter-year. 

Also, as a current student I have been interested in shadowing a few different labs. Management has been very helpful and more than willing to help me set up a time to get an overview of some other labs and spend a few hours observing which I appreciate.
cons:
Work is repetitive and can feel mundane at times. Also, although I was always comfortable asking questions I personally wasn't completely confident that I could fully perform my job after training but to be fair it does take me awhile to get a hang of things. It took me a few months afterwards to be really comfortable with the work/procedures. I understand the amount of trainers are somewhat limited and management wants to get new employees out on the floor in sufficient time while ensuring everyone is trained in an effective and standardized manner however, I think it would help to allow trainees more individual processing time with their trainers if needed. Everything felt somewhat rushed during training and there were some very common processing procedures I had completely forgot after I was assigned a pod however, my PST was very patient with me. All things considered training was still highly informative there was just an overwhelming amount of information at first.

Even though there are some negatives, all things considered it's an excellent place to work and a great company. I would highly recommend this job to others, students in particular.

review_title: Overall good experience but some flaws
job_title: IT Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits are almost top-notch for this type of a company (paying around $100/month for myself and my spouse for health, dental, and vision).  Other benefits include a free clinic, free gym, and a fairly nice cafeteria.  Most managers/supervisors are open-minded and are open to feedback.  Good culture for the most part (depending on the department) and most coworkers enjoy working for the company.
cons:
Pay is fairly sub-par across the board.  Making just under $20/hr ($40,000/year) for a job that at a similar company, could easily be making around $60,000 - $70,000/year.  They say this is due to the better benefits, which are great, but in my opinion, doesn't validate this huge difference in pay.  Work can be very stressful as most departments are understaffed but it can be rewarding depending on what you like to do and what type of work you are doing.  

Overall, I would say that the experience you have with ARUP mostly depends on the environment in which you work.  Culture varies heavily per department (with entry-level departments being the worst).  Certain managers are very nepotistic and don't reward hardworking employees but rather, reward the most social/outgoing employees.  I have seen that this is typically a major issue in our Client Services department but can be somewhat seen in other departments as well.  Job satisfaction really depends on what department you work in, what job you have, who you work with, and who your manager is.  it is not equally satisfying across the board.
